report_title: Prefabricated Home Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: The Prefabricated Home Manufacturing industry produces modular and manufactured homes that are low-cost substitutes for conventional, site-built units. The industry caters to first-time homeowners, retirees and low-income consumers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Falling Interest Rates Can Help and Hurt Manufacturers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Modular and manufactured homes are purchased as a low-cost alternative to conventional, on-site constructed housing. When traditional site-built homes drop in price and become more widely affordable, demand for manufactured and modular homes declines since consumers prefer to purchase traditional homes. Amid inflated prices for on-site constructed homes and low-interest rates, demand for prefabricated homes increased, especially among first-time homeowners and retirees. When conventional 30-year mortgage rates decline for site-built homes, the Prefabricated Home Manufacturing industry experiences an increased level of competition, which has mitigated the industry's growth during the period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Consolidation is Leading to Higher Profits
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Market share concentration in The Prefabricated Home Manufacturing industry has increased significantly. Industry consolidation has boosted profit during the period, as larger manufacturers benefit from economies of scale.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Recovering Economy Allows for More Trade
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: International trade in the industry has increased alongside demand, though remains minimal. Much of the growth in trade for this industry can be attributed to the economic recovery in 2022, which will spur globalization amid pent-up demand and normalizing supply chains.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Shifting Demand as Interest Rates Rise
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The primary substitutes include on-site constructed homes, apartment rentals, condominiums and townhouses. Industry manufacturers compete with these substitutes mainly based on price. The industry is at a disadvantage, particularly when interest rates rise, as most homeowners require financing. Consumers of all income levels will continue to prefer traditional homes over those built in a factory because of superior financing options and perceived value.

Industry manufacturers will rely on the growing senior population as the number of adults over 65 increases. Retirees will continue to grow as a market segment as they seek smaller, more cost-effective housing options. Young adults will continue falling as a share of industry demand, opting for rentals over purchasing a home. Consumer preferences among young adults are increasingly trending toward sustainable and eco-friendly housing options and companies that have already begun to focus on these preferences will be at an advantage.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising Demand Will Attract New Manufacturers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As demand for prefabricated and modular homes rises, the number of new entrants to the industry will increase. A rise in input costs, particularly the cost of sawmill lumber, will limit industry profit. Total employment will rise as more enterprises enter to employ workers.

industry_definition: Companies in the industry produce manufactured (mobile) and modular (prefabricated) homes and buildings, in addition to wood sections and panels for prefabricated buildings. Manufactured homes are constructed in a factory-controlled environment and often come equipped with wheels. Modular homes are manufactured in sections and then moved to the home site for final assembly.

positive_impact_factors: high - steady Barriers To Entry Level

key_trends: Demand for prefabricated and modular homes has been sustained by increases in per capita disposable income and access to credit.
Amid the COVID-19 pandemic, interest rates plummeted in an effort to stimulate the economy, making homes of all types, particularly prefabricated homes, more affordable.
Many consumers seeking to flee congested cities turned to prefabricated homes, especially as work-from-home policies granted
Manufactured homes are subject to local zoning and housing regulations
Prefabricated and modular housing units are a cheap substitute for more traditional on-site built homes
Manufactured housing is a regional business

The industry's main external competitor is on-site constructed homes. These houses have a more favorable public perception, which manufacturers have attempted to overcome through greater customization options for consumers. Competition with other industry manufacturers is based on product price and quality. Price is one of the most significant determinants since it is the main factor separating homes that are constructed on-site and mobile and prefabricated homes.
Prominent industry operators will continue gaining market share and consolidating through merger and acquisition activity, forcing many smaller participants to exit the industry.
High market share concentration in the industry means that average profit is heavily skewed toward major players.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Young, first-time homebuyers are a significant source of revenue as they have less disposable income and seek affordable housing options.
Older adults between these ages are also avid consumers of prefabricated and modular homes. Demand from this segment has grown recently.
Seniors and retired consumers living on fixed incomes keep expenses low by opting for prefabricated housing.

products_and_services.product_description: Houses constructed entirely in a factory rather than at the home site. Includes other buildings like sheds, farm buildings, etc.
Primarily consists of residential mobile homes, most of which are multi-section and more popular than single-section homes.
Includes mobile buildings like classrooms, offices, training rooms and other commercial buildings.

tier_1_suppliers: Gypsum Product Manufacturing in the US
Stone, Concrete & Clay Wholesaling in the US
Sawmills & Wood Production in the US
Construction Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Roofing, Siding & Insulation Wholesaling in the US
Construction & Mining Equipment Wholesaling in the US
Wood Paneling Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Manufactured Home Wholesaling in the US
Manufactured Home Dealers in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Young, first-time homebuyers with less disposable income seek more affordable housing options.
Older adults are avid consumers of prefabricated and modular homes. Demand from this segment has grown recently.
Seniors and retired consumers on fixed incomes opt for more affordable prefabricated housing.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Strong US dollar makes foreign goods cheaper for US consumers, boosting foreign demand. But manufacturers don't buy foreign products located far away due to transportation costs.
Canada and Mexico benefit from USMCA trade terms. Their proximity to US makes transporting products less burdensome.
Export revenue has been volatile. Exports fell sharply in 2020 due to pandemic disruptions but recovered in 2022. Heavily reliant on Canada's housing market.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has the highest percentage of establishments (30-40%) but lower population percentage (20-30%). Manufacturers locate here for easy access to raw materials like timber. The region is a major producer.
The West region has 10-20% of both establishments and population.
Manufacturers locate here for proximity to upstream markets and urban areas using prefab homes for redevelopment. Benefits from natural resources like lumber.
Second-most popular destination for sawmills, which are primary suppliers to the industry. Manufacturers locate near these upstream suppliers.

regulations_points.regulation_description: In 1976, the US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) issued regulations under the Home Construction Act establishing comprehensive national construction standards.

This regulation established a consensus committee to represent the industry and make recommendations that included imposing design standards to keep the HUD code up to date. The act also established that each state must develop a dispute resolution process.
Additionally, similar to other US manufacturers, companies within the industry are required to comply with environmental laws, which cover noise pollution, solid waste emissions and treatment.
The most apparent effect of the coronavirus pandemic on industry policy and regulation is the industry's designation as essential critical infrastructure at the outset of the pandemic period.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Labor is another essential requirement for entering the industry. Typical employees include floor staff, sales officers and staff for marketing, management, administrative and similar duties. Additionally, businesses will need to secure engineers, designers, contractors and other highly skilled employees.

basis_points.basis_description: The industry's main external competitor is on-site constructed homes. These houses have a more favorable public perception, which manufacturers have attempted to overcome through greater customization options for consumers.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition based on price and quality
basis_points.basis_description: Competition with other industry manufacturers is based on product price and quality. Price is one of the most significant determinants since it is the main factor separating homes that are constructed on-site and mobile and prefabricated homes.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Increase in consolidation due to weak demand
concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry has experienced substantial consolidation, with several companies being forced to exit, merge or be acquired by competing companies following tepid demand conditions.

Market share concentration increased substantially in 2020 alone, as the COVID-19 pandemic forced many small-scale companies to cease operation. Larger, more financially insulated competitors have captured an increasing portion of the market.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Milled hardwood and softwood like cut stock and dimension stock, Plywood and veneers, Resins and glue, Coatings like varnish and surfacing material.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Typical employees include floor staff, sales officers and staff for marketing, management, administrative and similar duties. Additionally, businesses will need to secure engineers, designers, contractors and other highly skilled employees.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patents and concentration
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The interest rate environment is the most substantial influencing factor for heightened volatility. As interest rates rise to relatively high levels, mortgage rates will follow suit, impacting the industry as consumers avoid buying homes.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Rising Prices and Income Affect Manufacturers
volatility_points.volatility_description: Volatility is dependent on price changes and the volume of prefabricated mobile homes and other wood buildings manufactured in the United States. The industry is susceptible to changes in demand for on-site constructed homes and per capita income levels.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: This product segment primarily consists of residential mobile homes, most of which are multi-section, which are more popular than single-section homes and represent the majority of sales in this category.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Prefabricated Wood Buildings Are Taking Over
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The prefabricated wood buildings segment includes houses constructed entirely in a factory rather than at the home site. This segment includes other buildings and structures constructed off-site, like sheds, farm buildings, chicken coops, sauna rooms, wood sections and panels for prefabricated wood buildings.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Nonresidential Mobile Buildings Attempt to Hold On
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: This segment includes mobile buildings like classrooms, offices, training rooms and other commercial buildings. This segment's share of total revenue will decline as the industry has experienced much more substantial demand growth for residential products.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by rising imports from abroad?
FAQs.answer: Due to the size of industry goods, imports of finished products are fairly minimal and mostly come from Canada. Imports fell in 2020 amid the COVID-19 pandemic but are anticipated to rise in 2022 as global supply chains normalize.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: As a housing-related product sales of mobile homes are highly cyclical and move roughly in line with residential construction. Industry revenue is expected to fall in 2022 in line with per capita consumer income.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to important suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers need to secure auto parts and other materials as inputs into their products, which could be disrupted by new protectionist trade measures.

FAQs.question: Has your company located in proximity to its key downstream distributors to reduce shipping costs? Have you explored strategic merger and acquisition activity?
FAQs.answer: Industry products are demanded nationwide, but many companies have focused on expanding distribution in the Southeast, which has a large retiree population. Strategic acquisitions can help penetrate previously untapped geographic markets, while enhancing the benefits of economies of scale.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Wage costs have declined relative to revenue over the past five years, but this is expected to be mostly an effect of higher capacity utilization amid strong demand.

FAQs.question: Does your company use SAP software systems to optimize all aspects of manufacturing, sales, inventory and distribution channels?
FAQs.answer: The industry's major players control their own distribution, and can gain major advantages by streamlining related processes. Implementation of these software systems can also effectively reduce labor and administrative expenses.

FAQs.question: How has your company adapted to coronavirus-related guidelines?
FAQs.answer: Social distancing, capacity limits, heightened sanitation procedures and other pandemic-related measures have significantly affected correctional facility operation.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to adjust to changing environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: The industry's profit margin is skewed by Berkshire Hathaway, which controls about half of the industry and is more profitable than the average player. Company-specific profit above or below industry average figures typically implies pricing power or weakness.

FAQs.question: How do you manage your assets and risks? Does your company have secure sources of revenue? How has your company adapted to the coronavirus operating environment?
FAQs.answer: The ability to manage company assets and service debts is critical in an industry where insolvency is a real risk. Insolvency has become the main industry risk amid the coronavirus pandemic as industry demand has faltered.

FAQs.question: Do you have contacts in retail and wholesale markets? How can you attain new contracts or extend existing ones?
FAQs.answer: Due to the high level of competition for sales of these products, contacts in wholesale and retail markets are critical to maintaining revenue. Different geographic markets have been disproportionately affected by industry revenue.

FAQs.question: Do you produce a broad range of products or specialize in only a few products? What training is required of your employees?
FAQs.answer: Since manufacturing this industry's products is labor intensive, having workers with a high degree of specialized knowledge is a key component of company success. Investing in employee staffing and development is crucial for maintaining a consistent and qualified workforce.

FAQs.question: Are you located in an area experiencing growth in the number of households? How has the level of household formation in your area affected demand?
FAQs.answer: A household is defined as a person or group of persons occupying a single housing unit, such as a house, apartment or mobile home.

FAQs.question: How has private nonresidential construction affected your company's revenue? How do you compensate for any declines in this market? How has the current low interest rate environment affected demand for your company?
FAQs.answer: Low-income consumers comprise the majority of industry demand because manufactured homes cost less than conventional homes. Monetary response to the coronavirus pandemic has significantly reduced benchmark interest rates. The 30-year conventional mortgage rate fell significantly in 2020 amid the COVID-19 pandemic but is expected to rise in 2022.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor trends in the house price index? How will you take advantage of this opportunity?
FAQs.answer: The house price index captures trends in average prices for the residential housing market. The value of residential properties has experienced mixed effects from the coronavirus pandemic based on geographic region. The house price index increased in 2020 and is expected to increase in 2022.
